name: LONDON SYSTEM
idea: The easiest system to learn! White plays the same moves regardless of Black's response: Bf4, e3, Nf3, Bd3, c3, Nbd2, 0-0. The structure is rock solid and the plan is always the same: build a pawn pyramid (d4-e3-c3) then attack on the kingside with Ne5, Qf3 or h4-h5. Ideal for beginners who want to avoid all theory and play familiar positions every game.
errors_white: Letting the Bf4 get exchanged by ...Bd6: the Bishop is the key piece, retreat to g3 if threatened
Playing e3 BEFORE Bf4: the Bishop stays locked in! Always bring out the Bishop first
Forgetting to play c3: this pawn protects d4 and prevents ...Nb4 or ...Bb4
errors_black: Playing passively: Black must counter-attack in the center with ...c5 or ...e5
Letting the white Knight settle on e5: this Knight becomes a monster, chase it with ...Nd7
Ignoring the h4-h5 attack: if White pushes h5 without opposition, the attack can be strong
development: ALWAYS to f4 on move 2 or 3 - that's the signature of the London!
Supports d4 and frees the Bf1 - play AFTER Bf4
Classical Nf3, then Ne5 when possible - strong square
Bd3 targets h7, the Bd3+Qc2 battery can be deadly
Nbd2 then Ne5 or Nf1-e3 to control central squares
Classical kingside castle - the position is very safe

traps.name: Bishop Trap
traps.desc: If Black plays ...Bd6 to exchange the Bishop, retreat Bg3! After ...Bxg3 hxg3 White has the open h-file for attack. AVOID (White): Never let it be taken on f4 - Bg3 keeps the Bishop.

traps.name: Knight Trap
traps.desc: White prepares Ne5. If Black ignores: Ne5 Nxe5?! dxe5 and White dominates. Then Bd3 and Qh5 threatens mate on h7! AVOID (Black): Play ...e6 and ...Bd6 to control e5.

traps.name: Queen Trap
traps.desc: After Bd3 and 0-0, the Qc2 + Bd3 battery targets h7. If Black castles without defending: Qc2 threatens Bxh7+! AVOID (Black): Play ...g6 or ...h6 before castling, or keep a Knight on f6.

variants.name: Classical London
variants.uci: d2d4 d7d5 c1f4 g8f6 e2e3 e7e6 g1f3 f8d6 f4g3
variants.white_plan: After Bxg3 hxg3, the h-file is open! Play Bd3, c3, Nbd2-e5 and Qc2 with pressure on h7.
variants.black_plan: Exchange the Bishop on g3 to weaken the attack. Play ...c5 to counter-attack in the center and free the game.

variants.name: Anti-King's Indian
variants.uci: d2d4 g8f6 c1f4 g7g6 b1c3 d7d5 e2e3
variants.white_plan: Against the fianchetto, the London stays solid. Plan: Nf3, Be2 or Bd3, 0-0 then h4-h5 to attack the fianchettoed King.
variants.black_plan: The Bg7 is less effective with solid d4. Play ...c5, ...Nc6 and seek ...e5 to open the diagonal.

variants.name: Jobava London
variants.uci: d2d4 d7d5 c1f4 g8f6 b1c3 e7e6 c3b5
variants.white_plan: Aggressive variation! Nc3 instead of Nf3 to jump to b5 and threaten c7. After ...Na6 or ...c6, White keeps the initiative.
variants.black_plan: Don't panic! Play ...a6 or ...c6 to chase the Knight. Then ...Bd6 and ...0-0 with a normal position.
